query: When the two ends of a strip of paper are glued together, forming a loop, it is called a circular ring. Cutting along the bisector of the paper strip will result in two circular rings. When a strip of paper is twisted 180 degrees and then the ends are glued together again, forming a loop, it is called a Mobius strip. Cutting along the bisector of the Mobius strip will result in a longer loop-like structure. If cut along the bisector of this longer loop-like structure, it will yield \_\_\_\_\_ loop-like structure again.
answers_list:
[reasoning process] Let's first understand what happens when we cut a Mobius strip along its center. A Mobius strip has one side and one edge, and cutting it along the center produces a single larger loop that is actually a two-sided shape. Now, this new loop can be thought of as a double strip because the cut transforms the original one-sided Mobius structure into a two-sided loop. 

Next, when we cut this new loop along its bisector, we essentially take a normal loop (which has two sides) and perform a cut through the middle. By doing this cut, we will end up with two separate loops that are not interconnected (similar to the result of cutting a standard circular ring). 

To summarize, the operations can be described in the following steps:
1. Start with a Mobius strip.
2. Cut the Mobius strip along the bisector, resulting in one loop with two sides.
3. Cut this new loop again along the bisector, which will yield two separate ordinary loops.

[Verification] Now, let’s verify: A Mobius strip becomes a two-sided loop when cut. When cutting an ordinary loop (a two-sided ring) along the center, we yield two separate loops. Thus, making a double verification that cutting the larger loop derived from the Mobius strip indeed results in two ordinary loops.

[Final Answer] The answer is 2 \n#### 2
